bioghist.p: Boris Blai was born in Rovno, Russia in 1893 and learned sculpture studying with Auguste Rodin in Paris. In 1917 Blai immigrated to the U.S. and he taught art at the Oak Lane Country Day School, an affiliate of Temple University. In 1935 Blai founded the Tyler School of Art located on the estate of Stella Elkins Tyler, a former student of his. During his 25 year tenure as Dean of Tyler Art School Blai created numerous sculptures and expanded upon his philosophy of art as an antidote for neuroses.

scopecontent.p: The papers of this prominent American sculptor and art educator document both Blai's personal life and his relationship with five different schools: the Long Beach Island Foundation of the Arts, the Boris Blai College of Contemporary Arts, Florida Southern College, Ocean County College, and Glassboro State College. The materials associated with these institutions includes minutes, press releases, course descriptions, and photographs. Blai's personal papers include correspondence, catalogs (exhibition), clippings, certificates, awards, handbills, postcards, telegrams, posters, sketches, and scrapbooks. The collection also contains materials relating to Blai's association with the Oak Lane Country Day School, the Tyler School of Art, and his early years in France. Prominent correspondents include R. Tait McKenzie and Stella Elkins Tyler.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
